description.narrative: The UNDP Accelerator Labs network will focused on development challenges by testing new ways of working to address social and environmental challenges.

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: 1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite - At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies 3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem

comment.narrative: 1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level - 0 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used - 0 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented - 0 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses - 0 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) - 0 blogs 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners - 0 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite - 0 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies - 0 3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs - 0 interactions 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network - 0 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network - no engagement 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem - no influence

1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level - 10 new sources of data per year 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used - 9 different type of data sources per year 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented - 50 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses - 10 innovation methods per Action Plan 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) - 10 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners - At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite - At least one government entity or partner has adopted an Accelerator lab method 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies - At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects 3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs - The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network, 48 interaction per year 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network - 50% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network - The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem - Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 10 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

1.1 12 new sources: Empathetic ethnography; Perspective Taking; Storytelling using vignettes, illustrations, and caricatures; Beneficiary Surveys; Informal Conversations with villagers; Deep listening using inclusive imaginaries; Formal Interviews with Ministry of iTaukei Affairs and iTaukei Affairs Board, for Gender; Archival Sources; Historical Data sources; Literature Review; Expert Interviews; Stakeholder consultations- Gender. 1.2 10 different type of data sources: Village profile data- Votua Village- Ba Province, and 2 villages in Kadavu Province; Survey Data as part of our experiments; Beneficiary Survey data for IRMU- monitoring and evaluation; Databases & excel based datasheets- experiment in Port Villa- Vanuatu; social media from virtual ethnography; Citizen-generated data from inclusive imaginaries; Socio-economic assessments from COVID sensemaking workshops; sourcing staff intelligence/data for MCPD workshop; insights/data generated through the General Staff Survey Taskforce- use of slido, one to one conversations, and interviews; positive deviant data through the small grants initiative offered through the Gov4Res- Resilience and Sustainable Development Programme. 1.3 119 Solutions were identified, collected and documented. 1.4 10 innovation methods per Action Plan: Sensemaking with the wider UN, Systems mapping; workshops; Deep Listening- Inclusive Imaginaries with Effective Governance Team; solutions mapping; technology innovation (hydroponics and biogas); Crowdsourcing; Portfolio Approach (Small Grants Initiative- with Gov4Res); virtual ethnography; prototyping; and Positive Deviance 2.1 8 Blogs; 1 report on Institutional Farm: Beqa- Yanuca Secondary School; 1 Exposure Story on Climate Exposure; 1 Publication on COVID-19 (Stories from the Pacific); 1 Discussion Paper: Climate finance effectiveness in the Pacific: are we on the right track?; 1 COVID-19 Rapid Policy Appraisal Paper (shared internally) 2.2 At least 80% of our learning challenges have the local NGOs (Beqa Lagoon Initiative; Pacific Blue Foundation), Regional NGOs (PIANGO; FLMMA), Government partners (Ba Provincial Council; Kadavu Provincial Council; Ministry of iTaukei Affairs; iTaukei Affairs Board; Ministry of Housing and Community Development- Fiji; Ministry of Internal Affairs- Vanuatu; Ministry of Health and Medical Services- Fiji; Ministry of Economy- Fiji; Ministry of Rural and Maritime Development and Disaster Management- Fiji), and local innovators (Fungs Farm, Isi Kakai, IntroGreen), as counterparts 2.3 The following Government entities has been supported and exposed to Accelerator Lab methods- particularly, foresight, futures, inclusive imaginaries and forecasting- Ba Provincial Council; Kadavu Provincial Council; Ministry of iTaukei Affairs; iTaukei Affairs Board; Ministry of Housing and Community Development- Fiji; Ministry of Internal Affairs- Vanuatu; Ministry of Health and Medical Services- Fiji; Ministry of Economy- Fiji; Ministry of Rural and Maritime Development and Disaster Management- Fiji 2.4 At least 80% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects (Anticipatory Governance (Social Innovation Platform)- Effective Governance; Experiments- Climate Security Project; Gender Equity and Social Inclusion, Climate Finance and Risk Informed Development, Monitoring and Evaluation Learning (MEL)); COVID-19 Socio Economic Taskforce Committee; Digital Clinic with Digital Advocate 3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network, Approximately 48-50 interactions per year 3.2 80% of information shared across the network is of methodology, cross pollination and cross fertilization of ideas and ways of working, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related, as well as learnings from the experiments 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 4 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least three times a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. The Accelerator Lab also has a dedicated online page (accessible from CO UNDP Page), including two accounts on Facebook known as Pacific Innovators and Solutions Holders and Accelerator Lab- Pacific from which ideas and insights in the form of solutions are shared with the Pacific Communities 3.4 Identified and engaged with 9 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

Test innovations/experiment with very light requirements Enables rapid delivery Allows linkage directly to the CO’s CPD, enabling full recognition of results and resource delivery at the country level GMS collected will be counted towards the CO’s total GMS collection Local resource mobilization can be easily applied to the CO’s Accelerator Lab Engagement Facility Recognizes accountability at country level

1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level - 2 new sources of data (User Experience data from TFOW4GE and Ethnographic Data from rural women farmers) 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used – 2 different kind of data sources: User Experience data from TFOW4GE, Ethnographic Data from rural women farmers) 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented - 21 new potential solutions 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses - 3 innovation methods (sensemaking, systems mapping, human-centered design) 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) - 4 blog posts 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners - 50% of our experiments had either a government partner (Fiji Ministry of Indigenous Affairs for Data Deep Dive) or the private sector entity as counterpart 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite - One government entity (Fiji Ministry of Indigenous Affairs) has learned about Accelerator lab methods 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies - 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects (PacFarmer app experiment for UNCDF Pacific Financial Inclusion Programme). 3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs – Individuals of the lab interacted at least three times a week with another lab in the network, more than 240 interaction per year 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network – 66% of information shared across the network was on methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network - The Lab team engaged around 4 times per month through WhatsApp, personal twitter accounts through FB messenger and through personal Instagram account, related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network. The AccLab staff also utilised Country Office official handles on social media accounts such as Twitter to engage with the broader development ecosystem. For example, the UNDP Twitter account mentioned the AccLab around once per quarter. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem – The AccLab identified and engaged with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem

1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level - 5 new sources of data per year 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used - 6 different type of data sources per year 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented - 35 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses - 5 innovation methods per Action Plan 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) - 6 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners - At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite - At least one government entity or partner has adopted an Accelerator lab method 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies - At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects 3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs - The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network, 48 interaction per year 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network - 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network - The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels, for example on UNDP CO Twitter account and the UNDP Accelerator Lab is tagged. The Lab team engages at least twice a month across social media such as WhatsApp, Twitter, Instagram and Facebook to discuss and disseminate learnings related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem - Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 10 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level – 8 sources of data (Village profile survey data Fiji, Participant Oberseration Tuvalu, Structured Interviews with Tuvalu government, walkabout and informal community engagement Tuvalu, people shadowing Tuvalu, citizen-generated data from school competition in Tuvalu and Sustainable Livelihoods Challenge Call Fiji, social media from virtual ethnography on Facebook, Socio-economic assessments (COVID sensemaking), Community Immersion (Vusama Village), Trend analysis & horizon scanning for COVID) 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used – 7 different kinds of data sources: Official government data from village profile surveys, Survey Data as part of our experiments, Solutions safari data, Databases & excel based datasheets, social media from virtual ethnography, Citizen-generated data from school competition and challenge call, and Socio-economic assessments from COVID sensemaking. 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented - 78 new potential solutions 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses - 8 innovation methods: Sensemaking, systems mapping, solutions mapping (including solution safari), technology innovation (hydroponics and biogas), Crowdsourcing (challenge call), virtual ethnography, prototyping, Positive Deviance 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) - 6 blog posts and one article published in an academic journal 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners - 100% of our experiments have either a government partner (Sigatoka Provincial Council for Vusama Saltmaking experiment) or the private sector (IntroGreen Distributors for hydroponics test in informal settlements) as counterpart. 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite - Two government entitities (Sigatoka Provincial Council and Fiji Ministry of Education) have learned about Accelerator lab methods. In addition, the entire UNCT adopted sensemaking and system mapping as part of the AccLabs support to formulating the UN’s socio-economic response to COVID-19 for Fiji and Vanuatu. 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies - 100% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects (Vusama Village Saltmaking Experiment for Fiji Ridge-to-Reef project, Hydroponics experiment to REACH project). 3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs – Individuals of the lab interacted at least three times a week with another lab in the network, more than 240 interaction per year 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network – 66% of information shared across the network was on methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network - The Lab team engaged around 2 ½ times per month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. The UNDP Twitter account mentioned the AccLab around once per quarter. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem – The AccLab identified and engaged with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem

1.1 5 new data sources per lab 1.2 9 different data sources per Lab. 1.3 25 new potential solutions per lab 1.4 V 8 per portfolio 2.1 10 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart 2.3 At least one government entity or partner has adopted an Accelerator lab method 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects 3.1 Each lab should interact at least once a week with another lab, a partner, and the global team. 3.2 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 10 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.
